content:
Never heard of that error before, so I tried google and one of the first things that popped up was one of my least favorite antivirus products. https://forum.kaspersky.com/topic/pr_connect_reset_error-on-firefox-35402/

Yes the issue is Firefox (Thunderbird and Firefox share basically the same code for the connection and network) Most of the fixes for Firefox also work with Thunderbird. Just the user interface to get to the settings is different.

I did have a look here https://cheapsslweb.com/blog/how-to-fix-pr-connect-reset-error-in-firefox and a few other sites with articles mentioning the error and it looks like they have a fairly standard diagnostic process before pointing the finger at the antivirus. 1. Clear the cache. (There is a button for that at the top of the troubleshooting information on the help menu.) 2. Disable security measures – antivirus & firewall (generally here, unless there is some clear reason, we do not suggest disabling Windows defender) 3. Disable and virtual private network(VPN) and proxy 4. Disable addons.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Thunderbird isn't the issue. The big problem people are being faced with is that their email providers have instituted a variety of ways to ensure only authorized customers can access their servers. So, the password a person uses on web access is often not the same one that is required when using an email client. I see posts every day from people, swearing their password is correct and that something is wrong with Thunerbird, only to learn that their password isn't authorized for an email client. I see regular posts about comcast, and this thread may be useful: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1413403
creator: davidsk

content: The provider and password had nothing to do with this issue. The issue was that I could not get Thunderbird to point to my old profile folder. Resolved now.

content:
I have no axe to grind here, I don't work for the folk that make Thunderbird and I am certainly not happy with the way the project is going, but I have been doing this support for Thunderbird gig for more than 10 years and I am seriously tired of folk coming to a support forum to vent their spleen. I didn't do anything! but apparently I and the others that volunteer here need to get the brunt of your misdirected invective. You are not telling "the man" anything as this is a peer support forum. If you have feedback, there is a link on the help menu in Thunderbird for that. Here you are dealing with other Thunderbird users.

I personally don't care if you use Thunderbird or not. That is your choice. I am offering to try and help, but if you want to go your own way and spend your limited funds on another mail client go right ahead. All I have an interest in is getting you and others like you back up and running. So now you have done the cranky consumer and have got that off your chest, can we work of fixing the issues? Or are you going to fork out your $80 or whatever it is and sign up for an office account with Microsoft so you can use Outlook. I do not use it because I like it less than Thunderbird, but I have a subscription.

For anyone on this forum to even begin to investigate the issues you complain about, we will need some more information. Lots more really as we know exactly what you tell us, and really about your issues I know nothing at all, except you say some accounts with an unknown mail provider have stopped working. Apparently over some extended but undefined period of time. As the quality of the support you will receive depends entirely on your ability to actually report issues clearly and provide information about the problem (including reporting error message). If the support is poor, it is usually a reflection on the quality information you supplied.

  1. What is the actual error message you receive from Thunderbird? (verbatim please)
  2. Who is the email provider providing the email service that is not working?
  3. How long has this been occurring? Did anything happen right before the problems started.
  4. If there are more than one mail account involved the details of each of those giving issues will be necessary.
    • Does Thunderbird work as expected in Thunderbird troubleshooting mode?
    • Does Thunderbird work as expected with your OS started in safe mode with Networking. Instructions for each operating system: Windows 10/11, Windows 8, Windows 7, OSX

creator: cvancant

content:
Even stranger! The taskbar icon is double counting only one inbox!

Let me explain. My Thunderbird serves two separate email addresses with their own separate inboxes. If inbox A receives two new messages and inbox B receives one new message, the Thunderbird taskbar tray icon will show (red circle number) 5 new messages. In contrast, if inbox A receives one new message and inbox B receives two, the icon will say 4 new messages. A single new message in A is shown on the icon as two; a single new message in B is shown as one. Clearly, the icon new message counter is double counting only inbox A. Very weird! This selective inbox A double counting happens constantly regardless of the combination and number of new messages for each inbox. This happens in real time as new messages come in. To repeat above, every other aspect of Thunderbird email works perfectly fine and the counts of all folders is correct within the Thunderbird window.

My Thunderbird is kept up-to-date and this double counting has been going on for at least 3 months.
creator: cvancant

content: In the case of Gmail every new mail appears in the inbox and the all mail folder. That is how they choose to implement IMAP. That is two.

content:
Here is my css code for Cards View: 

/* bold sender in cards view */ .thread-card-container :is(.sender){ 	font-weight: bold !important; 	color: blue !important; 	font-size: 15px !important; }  /* unread card sender */ tr[is="thread-card"][data-properties~="unread"] :is(.sender) {       color: black !important;       font-weight: bold !important;       font-size: 15px !important;    }     /* indent card subject */ .thread-card-subject-container :is(.subject){ 	margin-left: 10px !important; 	font-size: 13px !important; 	color: grey !important; }  /* unread card subject */ tr[is="thread-card"][data-properties~="unread"] :is(.subject) {       font-size: 13px !important;       font-weight: bold !important;    }  /* selected card bg color */ html|tr[is="thread-card"].selected {      background-color: lightgreen !important;  }


Help/Troubleshooting Info, Profile Folder, Open Directory (Win:Folder), close TB, create a new folder named chrome, create a new document in chrome with a text editor, name it userChrome.css, Save as type: All files *.*, copy in the above code, change the numbers and colours as desired. Double-click toolkit.legacyUserProfileCustomizations.stylesheets to true in Settings/General/Config. editor, restart TB.

Online css generator

video on how to create a css file (Firefox and TB)

The code to indent and style the Subject makes it distinct from the sender. Choose colours and fonts to suit your colour scheme.

content:
First. Do Not use IMAP for your purpose. It just will get you going in circles.

Second Then pop over to your gmail settings here https://mail.google.com/mail/u/0/#settings/fwdandpop Ensure POP is enabled and the gmail action when mail is accessed is to actually delete it.

Create a pop mail account in Thunderbird and ensure that the account settings in Thunderbird are set to delete mail on the server upon download.

That will do it going forward, and if you set pop in gmail to all mail, it will duplicate the already downloaded, but it will also remover the mail.

creator: aweissberg

content:
aweissberg said
I don't use MS Exchange.

Yes you do use MSexchange, that is what powers the whole hotmail/live/outlook/office365 mail thing. Microsoft only make and support one mail server software. That you are ignorant of a fact does not make it any less a fact.

The folders don't appear when I access outlook.com directly,

You are not doing that at all! You are accessing a website that displays mail data it gets from the mail server in any way it likes. In many regards Thunderbird also does that. Because both are mail clients, except one is a webpage and one is a product installed on your computer that is bound by the strictures of the IMAP mail protocol. The Outlook web site has no such limitation, because it uses Microsoft proprietary protocols to do just about everything it does. No open standards compliance required at Microsoft.

so it's not an Outlook problem.

Such closed thinking is most unlikely to get a result that you might consider a solution.

There was an earlier posting about this same issue and no solution offered beyond what I did, post with further info about my system settings.

Is there some point to this part of your posting? You provide no link for me to have any idea if it is even relevant to this discussion.

But what the, I will go over to google and look for the issue there without the blinkers of demanding the issue is not Outlook and is Thunderbird. Ohh look of found an article at Florida state university from 2021. It appears to me they are created by Microsoft Outlook, I guess the desktop or mobile app, but as I really use neither I do not know. I can only speculate how they came into existence. https://servicecenter.fsu.edu/s/article/What-do-I-need-to-know-about-the-authentication-certificate-used-for-FSUSecure-and-eduroam-1600352706829

Here is another article form a communications company that attempt to explain it to outlook users. As far as I can ascertain it has nothing to do with Thunderbird. https://support.intermedia.com/app/articles/detail/a_id/12123/~/what-is-the-outlook-synchronization-log%3F

Perhaps the earlier posting you refer to was from someone that was determined it was a Thunderbird issue, so restricted their thinking to Thunderbird and missed the elephant in the room because of it.

Reading in the later article, it appears that the folders are created by outlook locally, so I would guess someone has done an import from outlook somewhere along the line here.

Now to your point about deleting folders. IMAP has strong rules about this. Fundamentally the server will simply not delete some folders and they are transmitted to the IMAP client as folders that can not be deleted. These usually show up in Thunderbird interface a folder names in italic. For example the following image the [Gmail] folder can not be deleted.

Likewise you usually can not delete folders that contain mail, or in the case of these folders logs I guess.

So is the folder name in italics? Does it contain anything?
